questions.text: Cigar-shaped yeast in infected tissue is characteristic of _______.
questions.solution:
Cigar-shaped yeast is a feature of Sporotrichosis or rose gardener’s disease.

  • It is caused by dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Most commonly follows minor trauma like thorn prick etc in rose gardeners, forest workers, etc.
  • More common in Himalayan hilly areas (Himachal Pradesh).

Clinical features:

  • Nodules along the lymphatics later undergo necrosis and ulceration.
  • Spreads along lymphatics to lymph nodes which become enlarged, supportive, and indurated.
  • Other rare types – osteoarticular, pulmonary, disseminated type.

Diagnosis:

  • Cigar-shaped yeast in H & E stained tissue sections.
  • Culture – flower-like clusters of small conidia.
  • Asteroid bodies are formed due to the deposition of the immune complexes around the yeast cell. It consists of a central rounded or oval basophilic, cigar-shaped yeast cell surrounded peripherally by eosinophilic radiations
  • Latex agglutination test
  • Skin test – delayed hypersensitivity to sporotrichin.

Treatment:

  • Cutaneous form – Potassium iodide oral or topical
  • Lymphocutaneous form – Itraconazole
  • Disseminated infection – Amphotericin B

The above image reveals the conidiophores and conidia of the fungus Sporothrix schenckii during culture. Asteroid bodies are shown below.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child has a history of recurrent skin and respiratory tract infections. Investigations are carried out and a disorder of phagocytosis is suspected. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome is not a disorder of phagocytosis.

It is due to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches. Cell-mediated immunity is defective due to decreased T-cells. Affected individuals also have depressed graft rejection, hypocalcemia, and cardiac defects. 

Disorders of phagocytosis:

  • Leukocyte adhesion deficiency
  • Chediak–Higashi syndrome
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia

Other options: 

Option B: Leukocyte adhesion deficiency leads to defective neutrophil migration to sites of infection, peripheral neutrophilia, and recurrent infections without pus.

Option C: Chediak–Higashi syndrome is an autosomal-recessive disorder due to defects in lysosomal transport protein (LYST), leading to defective microtubule polymerization and defective phagolysosome formation. There is neutropenia and recurrent infections. 

Option D: Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase resulting in the absence of respiratory burst. It presents with recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

 

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: An epidemic of paralytic poliomyelitis occurs in a non-immune population. Which among the following strains of poliovirus is the most common cause of this?
questions.solution:
Type 1 poliovirus is the most common cause of epidemics in populations.

Poliovirus strains have been classified into 3 types: 

  • Type 1- most common and causes most of the epidemics. 
  • Type 2- endemic infections. 
  • Type 3- epidemics but rarer than type 1. 

Immunity is type-specific. 

Note :- Type 2 is declared eradicated in September, 2015 and Type 3 is declared eradicated in October, 2019

questions.text: Which of the following is false about exotoxin?
questions.solution:
Exotoxins are highly toxic whereas endotoxins moderately toxic. 

Differences between exotoxin and endotoxin:

Exotoxin

Endotoxin

Polypeptides

Lipopolysaccharides

Relatively unstable

Relatively stable 

Actively secreted by cells

Form part of cell wall

Diffuse into surrounding medium

Do not diffuse

Readily separable from culture

Obtained only by cell lysis

Enzymatic action

No enzymatic action

Specific pharmacologic effect for each exotoxin

Action common to all endotoxins

Specific tissue affinities

No specific tissue affinity

Active in very minute doses

Active only in large doses

Highly antigenic

Weakly antigenic

Action neutralized by antibody

Neutralization by antibody ineffective

Treatment with formaldehyde yields toxoid

Cannot be toxoided

Usually not pyrogenic

Pyrogenic

Highly toxic

Moderately toxic

Usually produced by gram positive bacteria; Some gram negative bacteria like Shigella dysenteriae, Vibrio cholera, ETEC

Usually produced by gram negative bacteria; Listeria is the only gram positive bacteria which produces endotoxin

questions.text: The average blood loss in case of infection with Necator americanus per worm per day is _______.
questions.solution: The average blood loss by the host per worm per day is 0.03 mL with Necator americanus and 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: The gene coding for DNA polymerase of Hepatitis B is _______.
questions.solution:
P gene codes for DNA polymerase.

Option a: S gene

It codes for surface antigen. It consists of the following:

  • S region → codes for S or major protein
  • 2 Pre S regions → Pre S1 codes for, L or large protein, Pre S2 codes for M or middle protein

Option d: C gene

  • When C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed
  • When translation begins from Pre C region, HBeAg is formed.

Option c: X gene codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the pneumococcal vaccine?

choices.text: Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPSV23 is indicated in splenectomized patients.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine  PCV13  is contraindicated in children less than 2 years.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPV 23 gives protection for 10 years.
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine is contraindicated if age > 65 years.

questions.solution:
Pneumococcal polyvalent vaccine PPSV23 is indicated in splenectomised patients.

There are two kinds of polyvalent pneumococcal vaccines:

  1. Pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine - PPSV23
    • It is indicated in splenectomized patients, sickle cell disease, immunocompromised patients, and patients above 65 years of age. 
    • CDC currently recommends the administration of one additional dose of PPSV23 at least 5 years after the last dose.
    • Children younger than 2 years old should not get this vaccine since they fail to mount an adequate response.
  2. Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine-
    • It includes PCV10 and PCV13.
    • It is indicated in children less than 2 years.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

questions.text: The causative agent of Bamble disease is ________.
questions.solution:
• Bamble disease (also known as Bornholm disease/Epidemic pleurodynia/Sylvest's disease/epidemic benign dry pleurisy/the devil's grip/epidemic myalgia/epidemic pleurodynia/epidemic transient diaphragmatic spasm/the Grasp of the Phantom) is caused by Coxsackie B virus.
  • Symptoms may include fever and headache, but the distinguishing characteristic of this disease is attacks of severe pain in the lower chest, often on one side. The slightest movement of the rib cage causes a sharp increase in pain, which makes it very difficult to breathe, and an attack is therefore quite a frightening experience. Due to this, the disease is also known as 'The Devil's grip'.

The illness lasts about a week and is rarely fatal. Treatment includes the administration of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents or the application of heat to the affected muscles.

questions.text: Erythrophagocytosis is a feature of _______.
questions.solution:
The trophozoite showing ingested RBCs is known as erythrophagocytosis.

This feature is specific for Entamoeba histolytica.

Besides, mature cyst is quadrinucleate.

Option b: Entamoeba coli has no ingested RBCs. The mature cyst of E. coli has 8 nuclei.

Option c: Entamoeba hartmanni has no ingested RBCs.

Related Pearl: Differential features of intestinal Entamoeba

Features E. histolytica E. coli E. hartmanni
   1. TROPHOZOITE
Size (µm) 12 - 60 20 - 50 4 - 12
Motility Active Sluggish Active
Pseudopodia Finger shaped, rapidly extruded Short, blunt, slowly extruded Finger shaped, rapidly extruded
Cytoplasm Clearly defined into endoplasm and ectoplasm Not defined Clearly defined into endoplasm and ectoplasm
Inclusion RBCs (erythro-phagocytosis), no bacteria Bacteria and other particles, no RBCs Bacteria and other particles, no RBCs
Nucleus Eccentric, not clearly visible in unstained films Visible in unstained films Not clearly visible in unstained films
Karyosome Small, central Large, eccentric Small, eccentric
Nuclear-membrane Delicate with fine chromatin dots Thick, coarse chromatin Coarse chromatin granules
   2. CYST   
Size (µm) 10 -15 10 - 30 5 – 10
Nuclei in mature cyst 4, central karyosome 8, eccentric karyosome 4
Glycogen mass Seen in uninucleate stage only Seen upto quadrinucleate stage Seen in uninucleate stage only
Chromatid bars 1-4, with rounded ends Splinter like with angular ends Numerous, irregular shape

questions.text: Which organism has the following cell wall structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of teichoic acid and lipoteichoic acid with a thick peptidoglycan layer is a feature of gram-positive bacteria. 

The cell wall of bacteria provides shape and ridigity to the bacterial cell. It is composed of peptidoglycans.

  Gram positive Gram negative
Teichoic acid, lipoteichoic acid Present Absent
Thickness (Peptidoglycan) Thicker Thinner
Variety of amino acids Few Several
Aromatic and sulfur-containing amino acids Absent Present
Lipopolysaccharides and outer membrane Absent Present

 

Other options:

Option C: The cell wall of fungi consists of chitin, mannan, and polysaccharides (glucan).

Option D: The cell wall of mycobacteria have mycolic acid, which is responsible for acid fastness.

questions.text: A microbiology resident is using the Lowenstein-Jensen medium as a selective medium for the culture of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. The presence of which of the following components makes it a selective medium?
questions.solution:
The presence of malachite green makes Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium a selective medium by inhibiting other bacteria. 

Contents of LJ medium:

  1. Egg: Provides fatty acids and protein required for metabolism.
  2. Malachite green: prevents the growth of contaminants.
  3. Mineral salt solution: Acts as a buffer.
  4. Glycerol: Source of carbon, favors the growth of M. tuberculosis, but not M. Bovis.
  5. L-asparagine: Source of Nitrogen.  

Mycobacterium tuberculosis colonies on LJ medium are dry, rough, raised, and irregular with a wrinkled surface. They are creamy white or buff-colored, tenacious, and difficult to emulsify (rough, tough, buff). 

Culture media used to cultivate Mycobacterium tuberculosis:

  • Solid culture media: Lowenstein–Jensen (A commonly used, egg-based, selective media).
  • Liquid culture media: Dubos' media, Middle Brook’s media. Virulent strains tend to form long serpentine cords in liquid media, while avirulent strains grow in a more dispersed manner.
  • Automated Culture Media: 
    • BACTEC 460: Uses radioisotopes
    • BacT/ALERT: A colorimetric method
    • BACTEC MGIT: A fluorometric detection method. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

Appropriate culture media for various bacteria:

Organism Medium for culture
Staph aureus Mannitol salt agar
ludlam’s medium
salt milk agar
Strep. Pyogenes Crystal violet blood agar
Neisseria meningitidis Thayer martin medium
Corynebacterium Potassium tellurite agar
Tinsdale medium
Mcleod medium
B.anthrax PLET medium
B.cereus MYPA (Mannitol egg yolk phenol red polymyxin agar)
PEMBA(polymyxin in egg yolk mannitol bromothymol blue agar
Clostridium  CCFA ( cefoxitin cycloserine fructose agar)
Shigella DCA, XLD, SSA
Salmonella Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium
Vibrio TCBS
Monsur GTTA
Pseudomonas Cetrimide agar
B.pseudomallei Ashdown medium
H. influenza Fildes agar
Levinthal medium
Bordetella Bordet-Gengou glycerine potato blood agar
Brucella Casteneda medium
B.burgdorferi BSK medium
Campylobacter

Skirrow's, Butzler's and Campy BAP media
Legionella pneumophilia

BCYE medium
Leptospira EMJH medium

questions.text: Which of the following is false about histoplasmosis?
questions.solution:
Person to person transmission or animal to man transmission is not yet known in case of histoplasmosis.

Transmission is mainly via inhalation of spores.

Spores in bird or bat droppings contaminate the soil which acts as reservoir of infection.

Histoplasmosis is endemic in USA. It has specific geographical distribution.

Histoplasma is thermally dimorphic fungus – yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at temperature of 37 °C and mycelial form occurs in soil at 25 °C.

questions.text: The anaerobic gram-positive bacillus showing reverse CAMP test positive is ______
questions.solution:
Reverse CAMP test is used for the identification of Clostridium perfringens.

Reverse CAMP test :
The test is called the reverse CAMP test because CAMP factor produced by Streptococcus agalactiae is used for the detection of Clostridium perfringens from other Clostridium species.

Principle:

  • A CAMP-positive group B Streptococcus is streaked in the center of sheep blood agar, and Clostridium perfringens is streaked perpendicular to it.
  • This is because of alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produce synergistic hemolysis.

questions.text: Which of the following disinfectants primarily affects the phosphate groups of the cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Cetrimide (acetyl trimetyl ammonium bromide) is a surface active agent that primarily acts on the phosphate groups of the cell membrane and also enters the cell. The membrane loses its semipermeability and the cell proteins are denatured. The most imporatnt bactericidal agents are the cationic surface active agents.

Option A: Formaldehyde acts against amino group of proteins.

Option B: Ethylene oxide acts by alkylating the amino, carboxyl, hydroxyl and sulfhydryl groups in proteins.

Option D: Gluteraldehyde acts by cross-linking proteins.

questions.text: Treg cells are ______
questions.solution: Treg cells or regulatory T cells are a subpopulation of CD4+ T cells. They regulate the acitivities of the T cells and provide tolerance to self antigiens and thus play a preventive role in the developement of auto-immune diseases. They express CD4 and CD25 on their surface. The most specific marker for these cells is FoxP3, which is localized intracellulary.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about antigenic drift?

choices.text: Due to point mutation and selection
New antigen related to previous antigen

questions.solution:
Antigenic drift is responsible for periodic epidemic.

Antigenic Drift:

  • Gradual sequential change in antigenic structure occurring regularly at frequent intervals
  • New antigens are still related to the previous ones, hence antisera to the previous antigens still reacts to the new antigens.
  • It is due to the mutation and selection.
  • It accounts for the periodic epidemic.

Antigenic Shift:

  • It is an abrupt, drastic, discontinuous variation in the antigenic structure.
  • New virus is unrelated to the predecessor strains.
  • Antibodies to predecessor strains do not neutralize the new variants.

questions.text: A positive catalase test and bacitracin sensitivity are shown by ______.
questions.solution:
A positive catalase test and bacitracin sensitivity are shown by micrococci.

A positive catalase test is given by both Staphylococcus and Micrococcus.

 Differentiation between Staphylococcus and Micrococcus:

Test Staphylococcus Micrococcus
OF test Fermentative Oxidative
Furazolidone Sensitive Resistant
Bacitracin Resistant Sensitive

questions.text: Barrel-shaped arthroconidia as depicted in the below image is a feature of _______
questions.solution:
Coccidioides immitis is a dimorphic fungus that exists in two distinct forms, saprophytic and parasitic.

In the soil, the organism exists as a mould with septate hyphae resembling the shape of a barrel. When entering a host, the arthroconidia (spores) break off from the hyphae and evolve into round structures called spherules. When inside the host, spherules grow and undergo internal division, forming smaller structures called endospores.

Around 60% of infected individuals remain completely asymptomatic. The rest 40% have respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, and pleuritic chest pain which develop from days to 2 weeks after inhalation of infectious spores.

questions.text: The cytopathic effect of large granular clumps resembling grapes is caused by ________.
questions.solution:
The cytopathic effect of formation of large granular clumps resembling grapes is caused by Adeno virus.

Related Pearl: Cytopathic effects caused by viruses

Morphological changes in the cells that are caused by viruses are known as cytopathic effects (CPE) and the viruses causing these CPEs are known as cytopathogenic viruses. These CPEs can be detected by a light microscope.

Type of cytopathic effect

Virus

Rapid crenation of cells and degeneration of the cells

Enterovirus

Syncytium/multinucleated giant cell formation

Measles, mumps, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)

Discrete focal degeneration

Herpes virus

Large granular clumps resembling grapes

Adenovirus

Cytoplasmic vacuolation

Simian virus 40 (SV 40)

questions.text: Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by  ________.
questions.solution:
Kanagawa phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahemolyticus.

  • On Wagatsuma agar (blood agar with 2% salt), pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic.
  • This is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to the OPD with fever and malaise for the past 4 months. On examination, the following ocular finding is noted along with hepatosplenomegaly and lymphadenopathy. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the image showing Romana's sign is suggestive of Chagas disease.

It is caused by T. cruzi. Reduviid bugs are vectors for Chagas disease.

Inoculation of T. cruzi in conjunctiva causes unilateral, painless edema of periocular tissues in the eye is called Romana’s sign. This is classically seen in acute Chagas disease that lasts for 1 to 4 months.

The following image shows a patient with Romana's sign.

Acute Chagas disease is also characterised by the presence of chagomas which are subcutaneous lesions occurring at the site of inoculation.

Chronic Chagas disease is characterized by megaesophagus, megacolon, and myopathy.

Shown below is an image of the Reduviid bug.

questions.text: The complement formed in liver is ________.
questions.solution:
Complements C3, C6, and C9 are produced in liver.

Synthesis of complement:

C1

Intestinal epithelium

C2, C4

Macrophages

C5, C8

Spleen

C3, C6, C9

Liver

questions.text:
Match the following:
A. Darling disease   I. Blastomycosis
B. Valley fever  II. Histoplasmosis
C. Gilchrist's Disease III. Paracoccidiomycosis
D. South American blastomycosis  IV. Coccidiomycosis
questions.solution:
• Histoplasmosis is also known as Cave disease,Darling's disease, Ohio valley disease,reticuloendotheliosis,spelunker's lung and caver's disease.
  • Valley fever, also known as, desert fever, San Joaquin Valley fever, coccidioidomycosis, and desert rheumatism is a fungal infection caused by Coccidioides.
  • Blastomycosisalso known as North American blastomycosis, Blastomycetic dermatitis, and Gilchrist's disease is a fungal infection of humans and other animals, notably dogs and occasionally cats, caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis.
  • Paracoccidioidomycosis, also known as Brazilian blastomycosis, South American blastomycosis,Lutz-Splendore-de Almeida disease and paracoccidioidal granuloma, is a fungal infection caused by the fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

questions.text: Quorum sensing in prokaryotes involves ________.

choices.text: Regulation of genes involved in diverse physiologic processes

questions.solution:
Quorum sensing is the regulation of gene expression in response to fluctuations in cell-population density.

  • It is a cell–cell communication mechanism to regulate the transcription of genes involved in diverse physiologic processes, including bioluminescence, plasmid conjugal transfer, and the production of virulence determinants.
  • It depends on the production of one or more diffusible signal molecules termed autoinducers or pheromones that enable a bacterium to monitor its own cell population density.
  • It is an example of multicellular behavior in prokaryotes.

questions.text: Identify the organism causing the lesion shown in the image below in a severely immunocompromised person which is diagnosed using Warthin starry silver stain.
questions.solution:
• B. henselae is observed more commonly in immunodeficient patients.
  • The image shown above is bacillary angiomatosis, in which vascular nodules or tumours appear on the skin, mucosa, and other locations.
  • Angiomatosis may also be due to B. quintana.
  • However, demonstration of bacteria using Warthin starry staining of the lymph node biopsy smears is confirmatory test for B. henselae.

questions.text: The causative agent of shipyard eye is _______.
questions.solution:
Shipyard eye refers to epidemic keratoconjunctivitis caused by adenovirus type 8.

This virus normally causes common cold syndrome, but it can also be transmitted to the eye, where it may cause corneal opaqueness. When transmitted by water, the infection is called shipyard eye.

questions.text: The causative agent of lesion in the given image is ______.
questions.solution:
The above image shows lesions caused by fungus Malassezia globosa. 

It causes Pityriasis versicolor – hyperpigmented macules and patches over back and chest. M. globosa appears to be the predominant causal species in tinea versicolor.

Option a: Piedraia hortae (Piedraiaceae) is a non-pathogenic opportunist that infects human hair causing black piedra which is characterised by the formation of dark, hardened nodules (hence piedra, stone) firmly attached to hair.

Option b: Exophiala werneckii/Hortaea werneckii/Phaeoannellomyces werneckii/Cladosporium werneckii causes tinea nigra – gray to black non inflammatory, non scaling, well demarcated macular lesions usually on palm.

Option d: Microsporum causes dermatophytosis/tinea/ringworm.

questions.text: The coreceptor for macrophage trophic strains of HIV is _______.
questions.solution: Binding of envelope glycoprotein gp120 to CD4 receptor requires the participation of a co-receptor CXCR 4 for T cell tropic HIV strains and CCR 5 for macrophage-tropic strains.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days.  A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?

choices.text: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
pLDH antigen test is specific for detection of the causative agent
Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat method
Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy

questions.solution:
High-grade fever, chills and the peripheral smear showing double chromatin ring forms are suggestive of P. falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specific for P. falciparum. pLDH is positive for all Plasmodium spp. 

Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographic methods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between species except P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are:

  • pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase): Pan-malarial antigen
  • HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2): Specific for P.falciparum.

Parasite-F test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of HRP-2. The dual antigen test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of both pLDH and HRP-2. 

Other diagnostic methods include microscopy of peripheral blood smears, quantitative buffy coat, culture and molecular diagnosis. Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral blood smears. In quantitative buffy coat, a small quantity of blood is centrifuged. The RBCs containing malarial parasites settle just below the buffy coat of leukocytes, on top of the normal RBCs. The tube is precoated with acridine orange dye, which induces fluorescence in the parasites (the dye stains nucleic acids which are absent in mature RBCs). The parasites appear greenish-yellow against a red background.

questions.text: The mechanism of action of Exotoxin A of Pseudomonas resembles that of _______ toxin.
questions.solution:
Exotoxin A of Pseudomonas causes ADP ribosylation of EF-2 similar to diphtheria toxin and thus inhibits protein synthesis.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding MHC molecules?

choices.text: MHC class II presents peptide antigen to CD4 T cells.
Peptide-binding site for MHC class I is α1/α2 groove.
MHC Class II presents endogenous antigens.
β2 of MHC II binds to CD4 on TH cells.

questions.solution:
MHC class I presents endogenous antigens, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC CLASS I

MHC CLASS II

Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets

Present on antigen presenting cells

Presents endogenous peptide antigen to  CD8+ T cells

Presents exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway

Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove

Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove

CD8 molecules bind cytotoxic T cells

CD4 molecules bind helper T cells

questions.text: Identify the contributions of the scientist in the image given below.

choices.text: First to observe and report bacteria

questions.solution:
The image shows Robert Koch who discovered Anthrax bacilli.

  • Contributions of Robert Koch (Father of Medical microbiology)
  • Discovered tubercle bacilli, anthrax bacilli, Vibrio cholera
  • Staining techniques Solid culture techniques

Option b: Louis Pasteur discovered vaccine for rabies.

Contributions of Louis Pasteur (Father of microbiology): 

  • Disproved theory of spontaneous generation
  • Formulated germ theory
  • Discovered pasteurization, sterilization techniques, fermentation
  • Coined the term vaccine and microbiology
  • Vaccine for rabies, chicken pox, cholera and anthrax  

Option c: First to observe and report bacteria was Antony Van Leeuwenhoek

Option c: Small pox vaccine was discovered by Edward Jenner.

questions.text: Which among the following differentiates Neisseria meningitidis from Neisseria gonorrhea?
questions.solution:
• Meningococcus can ferment glucose and maltose, whereas Gonococcus can ferment only glucose.
  • Hence, the ability of Neisseria meningitidis to ferment maltose differentiates it from Neisseria gonorrhea.

questions.text: Prausnitz Kustner reaction demonstrates _______.
questions.solution:
The Prausnitz–Küstner (P–K) reaction is a sensitive method to test for the presence and activity of immunoglobulin E in the skin of an individual . IgE is an important class of immunoglobulin mediating allergic reactions. 

  • In this method, the  serum is injected from an allergic person into the skin of a nonallergic individual. When the appropriate antigen was later injected into the same site, a wheal and flare reaction there is evidence that the suspected antigen is causing the hypersensitivity. 
  • Because of the danger of transmitting viral hepatitis and AIDS, this test is no longer used.

questions.text: Which among the following species is viviparous?
questions.solution:
Trichinella spiralis is viviparous i.e. produces larva.

Enterobius vermicularis and Ascaris lumbricoides are oviparous i.e. produces egg.

Female nematodes are classified as follows

  • Oviparous – laying eggs
    • Unsegmented eggs: Ascaris, trichuris
    • Segmented eggs:  Ancylostoma, Necator
    • Eggs containing larva : Enterobius
  • Viviparous – Producing larvae E.g., trichinella, wuchereria, brugia

Ovoviviparous – laying eggs containing fully formed larvae which hatch out immediately. E.g., strongyloides

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true?

choices.text: Ergosterol is present in cell wall of fungus
Aspergillus has septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
Aspergillus is a mould/filamentous fungi. It has septate hyphae with dichotomous branching at acute angles.

Option a: Cryptococcus is a unicellular yeast.

Option b: Ergosterol is present in cell membrane and not cell wall of fungus. Cell wall contains chitin, mannan, and polysaccharide (glucan).

Option c: Ascospore is a sexual spore produced by Ascomycetes.

questions.text: A microbiologist observes the following growth on a blood agar plate. Which of the following will not be the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a swarming type of growth on the agar plate. It will not be caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

Swarming is the growth of motile bacteria in the form of a thin film on solid culture media. It is exhibited by the following:

  • Gram-positive bacilli - Clostridium tetani (option A), Bacillus cereus (option D)
  • Gram-negative bacilli - Proteus mirabilis (option C), Proteus vulgaris
  • Gram-negative halophilic bacteria- Vibrio parahaemolyticus 

Swarming can be inhibited by increasing the concentration of agar (6%), alcohol, sodium azide, boric acid, chloral hydrate, sulfonamide, and surface-active agents.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses has been depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows a filamentous virus, hence, it is most likely to be the Ebola virus. 

Option A: Corona virus has petal/club-shaped peplomers radiating like sunrays.

 

Option B: Adenovirus is space-vehicle shaped.

 

Option D: Rabies virus is bullet shaped.

questions.text: Eucalyptus camaldulensis is involved in transmission of _______.
questions.solution: Eucalyptus camaldulensis is a natural reservoir of Cryptococcus neoformans.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presented with bilateral lower limb non-pitting edema and milky white urine. On examination, a hydrocele was also seen. A night sample of blood is taken and is sent for thick and thin stained smears. The following image seen on the blood smear shows which organism?
questions.solution:
The image shows Wuchereria bancrofti. The clinical picture is suggestive of elephantiasis. The image demonstrates sheathed microfilaria with nuclei-free tail tip.

The disease can present as classical filariasis or occult filariasis. Clinical features include:

Classical filariasis- Fever, lymphangitis, hydrocele, elephantiasis(non-pitting brawny edema), milky white urine(chylous), etc.

Occult filariasis- Massive eosinophilia, hepatosplenomegaly, dyspnea, arthritis, glomerulonephritis, etc. 

Diagnosis is confirmed by the demonstration of microfilaria in blood, chylous urine, exudate of lymph varix, and hydrocele fluid.  The filarial species is nocturnally periodic,  hence it is preferable to collect night blood samples between 10 pm and 4 am. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Image showing elephantiasis:

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

Related Pearl: Important serological tests for the diagnosis of parasitic infections

Serological tests are helpful for the detection and surveillance of many protozoal and helminthic infections.

These tests are basically of 2 types:

  • Tests for antigen detection
  • Tests for antibody detection

Antigen Detection:

Antigen

Parasite

Galactose lectin antigen

Entamoeba histolytica

Giardia-specific antigen 65

Giardia lamblia

WKK and rk39 antigen

Leishmania donovani

HRP-2 antigen

Plasmodium falciparum

Vivax-specific pLDH

Plasmodium vivax

200 KD Ag and OG4C3 antigen

Wuchereria bancrofti

 

Antibody detection:

  • Complement fixation test (CFT)
  • Indirect hemagglutination test (IHA)
  • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFA)
  • Rapid immunochromatography test
  • ELISA test

questions.text: A man presents with fever, chills and abdominal pain for 1 week. He underwent valve replacement for symptomatic aortic valve stenosis 4 months ago. On auscultation, an early diastolic murmur is noted along the lower left sternal margin which increases in intensity during the Valsalva maneuver. Which of the following statements is true about the most common organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
Fever and chills with aortic regurgitation (an early diastolic murmur along the left sternal margin increasing in intensity during the Valsalva manoeuvre) in a patient with a prosthetic valve suggest a diagnosis of prosthetic valve left-sided infective endocarditis. The most common organism causing it within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS). Its cell wall contains teichoic acid. 

Infective endocarditis is the microbial infection of heart valves or endocardium, leading to the formation of vegetations (thrombotic debris and microbial organisms). Patients present with fever, chills and heart murmurs. Non-cardiac manifestations like subungual hemorrhage, Osler's nodes and arteria emboli may be seen. The most common organism causing IE overall is Staphylococcus aureus. The most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis within 12 months of surgery is coagulase-negative Staphylococci, like Staphylococcus epidermidis. 

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a Gram-positive coccus arranged in clusters. It is coagulase-negative (option B) and is resistant to lysostaphin (option D). It is non-hemolytic (option C). It is a part of normal flora of the human body.

The following image shows a graphical illustration of vegetations seen in infective endocarditis.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Hepatitis A virus?

choices.text: HAV is transmitted by feco-oral route
Formalin inactivated anti-HAV vaccine is now available

questions.solution:
• Hepatitis A virus is a small, 27-nm, nonenveloped, single-stranded RNA virus in the Picornavirus family.
  • Hepatitis A is transmitted by feco-oral route.
  • Formalin-inactivated, alum-conjugated vaccine containing HAV grown in human diploid cell culture is available.

questions.text: A throat swab taken from a patient who presented with fever, dysphagia and cervical lymphadenopathy was sent for culture on potassium tellurite agar. The resultant colonies had a poached egg appearance. Which among the following is the most likely organism implicated here?
questions.solution:
Poached egg colonies on potassium tellurite agar indicate Corynebacterium diphtheriae mitis.

Macleod classified diphtheria bacilli based on colony morphology on tellurite blood agar into the following three types:

  • Gravis: They form daisy head colonies and are variably hemolytic. They ferment glycogen and starch. 
  • Intermedius: They form frog’s egg colonies and are non-hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.
  • Mitis: They form poached egg colonies and are hemolytic. They do not ferment glycogen and starch.

The following image shows the various colony morphologies of C. diphtheriae.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis has jerky or twitching type of mobility.

Option a: Trichomonas has no cystic stage.

Option c: Concave sucking disc is a feature of Giardia lamblia.

Option d: Sexual transmission is the main route of infection. Other modes are fomites, babies during passage through infected birth canal.

questions.text: Which among the following is an enveloped DNA virus?
questions.solution:
• Herpes virus is an enveloped DNA virus.
  • Adenovirus is non enveloped DNA virus.
  • Japanese encephalitis virus is an enveloped RNA virus.
  • Picornavirus is non enveloped RNA virus.

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

questions.text: The given below appearance is related to _______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Maltese cross appearance, characteristic of Babesia.

Babesia:

  • Definitive host – Ixodid ticks
  • Intermediate host – Man
  • Intraerythrocytic parasite
    • Round or pyriform, or ring form simulating falciparum.
    • The ring form is the most common and lacks the central hemozoin deposit, typical of falciparum.
    • Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and presence of tetrads (maltose crosses), which are pathognomic of microti or B. duncani.
  • Texas fever – Hemolytic disease in cattle.
  • In man:
    • Mode of infection – bite of tick/RBC transfusion (occasionally)
    • Severe babesiosis - >4% parasitemia
  • Treatment:
    • Mild – Atovaquone + Azithromycin
    • Severe – Clindamycin + quinine
    • Fulminant case – exchange transfusion

questions.text: The causative agent of the lesion given in the image below is _______.
questions.solution:
The image above shows lesions of hand, foot, and mouth disease. It is caused by Coxsackie virus A16, A9, and B 1-3.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease is an exanthematous fever. It mainly affects young children. It presents as clusters of papulovesicular lesions on the skin of the hand, foot, and oral mucosa.

questions.text: Sereny test was employed for laboratory diagnosis of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The Sereny test is an animal pathogenicity test that used to be employed for laboratory diagnosis of enteroinvasive E. coli and Shigella.

Freshly isolated suspension of bacteria is instilled into the eyes of guinea pigs which leads to mucopurulent conjunctivitis and severe keratitis.

It is not in use anymore as we have better methods of detecting toxigenicity now like molecular methods.

questions.text: IL-2 is secreted by _______.
questions.solution:
IL-2 previoulsy known as T cell growth factor is produced by T lymphocytes.

Function:

  • Promote growth and differentiation of T and B cells
  • Cytotoxicity of T and NK cells
  • Secretion of other lymphokines
  • Conversion of null cells into lymphokine activated killer cells that destroy NK cell-resistant tumor cells
